verses.text: In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth.
verses.comment: This verse establishes that God alone is the eternal Creator. The use of 'beginning' connects to John 1:1, showing how all things were made through the Word (the Logos), which points to Christ's role in creation. The phrase 'the heavens and the earth' means the entire universe.

verses.text: The earth was formless and empty, and darkness was over the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God was hovering over the face of the waters.
verses.comment: 'Spirit of God' is understood both as the divine presence preparing creation and, in later Christian tradition, as the Holy Spirit. The triple mention of God, Spirit, and the creative Word in these verses foreshadows the Trinity.

verses.text: And God said, 'Let there be light,' and there was light.
verses.comment: Creation occurs through God's word. This anticipates the power of the divine Word (see John 1 and Col. 1:16). Light here is symbolic of God's presence and life.

verses.text: And God saw that the light was good. And God separated the light from the darkness.
verses.comment: The act of separating light from darkness begins God's ordering work in creation. 'Good' reflects God's perfect will—creation is good because it comes from God.

verses.text: And God called the light Day, and the darkness he called Night. And there was evening and there was morning, the first day.
verses.comment: God's act of naming shows authority. The cycle of evening and morning forms the first of the creation days.

verses.text: And God said, 'Let there be an expanse in the midst of the waters, and let it separate the waters from the waters.'
verses.comment: The 'expanse' (sky or firmament) introduces structure to creation. The text shows God bringing order where there was chaos.

verses.text: And God made the expanse and separated the waters that were under the expanse from the waters that were above the expanse. And it was so.
verses.comment: An ancient view of the cosmos, yet ultimately pointing to God's sovereignty over all things seen and unseen.

verses.text: And God called the expanse Heaven. And there was evening and there was morning, the second day.
verses.comment: The naming by God reaffirms His authority. The day-structure signals an ordered creation.

verses.text: And God said, 'Let the waters under the heavens be gathered into one place, and let the dry land appear.' And it was so.
verses.comment: The gathering of waters reveals God's power to command creation. This prefigures themes of baptism and rebirth, where God brings forth life from chaos.

verses.text: God called the dry land Earth, and the gathered waters he called Seas. And God saw that it was good.
verses.comment: Naming the Earth and Seas shows sovereignty. Declaring goodness points to creation as reflecting God's perfect wisdom.

verses.text: Then God said, 'Let the earth sprout vegetation, plants yielding seed, and fruit trees bearing fruit according to their kind, with seed in it, upon the earth.' And it was so.
verses.comment: God creates through his word. The diversity in creation shown here is echoed in the spiritual diversity and fruitfulness within the people of God.

verses.text: The earth brought forth vegetation: plants yielding seed according to their kinds, and trees bearing fruit with seed in it according to their kinds. And God saw that it was good.
verses.comment: The creation acts in accordance with God's word and order. The theme of fruitfulness is echoed in New Testament teachings on spiritual fruit.

verses.text: And there was evening and there was morning, the third day.
verses.comment: The pattern of God's work and rest sets up cycles of sacred time, reflected throughout the Scriptures.

verses.text: And God said, 'Let there be lights in the expanse of the heavens to separate the day from the night. And let them be for signs and for seasons, and for days and years,
verses.comment: Creation of lights shows God's establishment of time and seasons, essential for the liturgical life that develops later in Scripture.

verses.text: and let them be lights in the expanse of the heavens to give light upon the earth.' And it was so.
verses.comment: The lights serve the earth, highlighting God's design for creation to sustain and bless life.

verses.text: And God made the two great lights—the greater light to rule the day and the lesser light to rule the night—and the stars.
verses.comment: In contrast to ancient beliefs that worshipped the sun or moon, Scripture shows these lights as mere creations under God's rule.

verses.text: And God set them in the expanse of the heavens to give light upon the earth,
verses.comment: The purpose of the heavenly bodies is to benefit the earth—a sign of God's care for creation.

verses.text: to rule over the day and over the night, and to separate the light from the darkness. And God saw that it was good.
verses.comment: Ordering the cosmos, God’s creative acts are both physical and spiritual, symbolizing victory of light over darkness—a motif fulfilled in Christ (see John 8:12).

verses.text: And there was evening and there was morning, the fourth day.
verses.comment: Each day ends with a refrain, marking sacred time—a pattern reflected later in the rhythm of worship.

verses.text: Then God said, 'Let the waters swarm with living creatures, and let birds fly above the earth across the expanse of the heavens.'
verses.comment: Creation of animals in the sea and sky shows the fullness and abundance from God's command. Life in all its variety is dependent on God.

verses.text: So God created the great sea creatures and every living creature that moves, with which the waters swarm, according to their kinds, and every winged bird according to its kind. And God saw that it was good.
verses.comment: 'Created' here uses the unique verb for God's creative act. All creation receives God’s blessing and order.

verses.text: And God blessed them, saying, 'Be fruitful and multiply and fill the waters in the seas, and let birds multiply on the earth.'
verses.comment: God’s blessing imparts both physical life and an ongoing generative power.

verses.text: And there was evening and there was morning, the fifth day.
verses.comment: The sacred seven-day structure continues—an important foundation for practices of rest and worship in Scripture.

verses.text: And God said, 'Let the earth bring forth living creatures according to their kinds—livestock and creeping things and beasts of the earth according to their kinds.' And it was so.
verses.comment: This further demonstrates God’s ordering will and variety in creation.

verses.text: And God made the beasts of the earth according to their kinds and the livestock according to their kinds, and everything that crawls on the ground according to its kind. And God saw that it was good.
verses.comment: Repetition of 'according to their kinds' underscores created order and the sufficiency of all creatures within God's providence.

verses.text: Then God said, 'Let us make man in our image, after our likeness. And let them have dominion over the fish of the sea and over the birds of the heavens and over the livestock and over all the earth and over every creeping thing that creeps on the earth.'
verses.comment: 'Let us make' hints at the divine counsel, foreshadowing Christian understanding of the Trinity. Human dignity arises from being in God’s image, a foundation for the spiritual life and ethics.

verses.text: So God created man in his own image, in the image of God he created him; male and female he created them.
verses.comment: Man and woman alike bear the image of God—this spiritual dignity is the foundation of Christian anthropology. The duality here finds spiritual fulfillment in New Testament teaching on the union of Christ and the Church (see Eph. 5:32).

verses.text: And God blessed them. And God said to them, 'Be fruitful and multiply and fill the earth and subdue it, and have dominion over the fish of the sea and over the birds of the heavens and over every living thing that moves on the earth.'
verses.comment: The blessing to be fruitful and exercise dominion is granted to humanity as stewards of creation. This blessing also shows that God's plan involves family and propagation, laying groundwork for sacramental views of marriage and life.

verses.text: And God said, 'Behold, I have given you every plant yielding seed on the face of all the earth, and every tree with seed in its fruit. You shall have them for food.
verses.comment: Original provision is solely plant-based. This ideal is later affected by the fall (see Gen. 9:3). God's care for humanity is evident.

verses.text: And to every beast of the earth and to every bird of the heavens and to everything that creeps on the earth, everything that has the breath of life, I have given every green plant for food.' And it was so.
verses.comment: All living things receive God's provision, showing His goodness to all creation.

verses.text: And God saw everything that he had made, and behold, it was very good. And there was evening and there was morning, the sixth day.
verses.comment: God declares all creation 'very good' after making humanity, climaxing the order of creation. This recognition of original goodness underlies all later doctrines of grace and redemption, fulfilled in Christ (see John 1:14; Rom. 8:21).
